Learn the basics of Jetpack Compose, including setting up your environment and creating your first composable.
Dive into Compose layouts, theming, and styling your app.
Manage state effectively and navigate between screens in your Compose app.
Explore advanced Jetpack Compose topics like animations, custom layouts, and performance optimization.
Are you sure you want to reset your progress for all courses? This action cannot be undone.
The simplest way to display text is to use the |Text| composable.\nIt has one required parameter: the string to display.
This code will display the following text:
The |Text| composable has multiple optional parameters that you can use to change its content appearance.

Jetpack Compose also provides other font weights: |Thin|, |ExtraLight|, |Light|, |Normal|, |Medium|, |SemiBold|, |ExtraBold|, and |Black|.\nYou can also create custom font weight by passing an Int to the constructor.
You can add shadow to the text by creating a new |TextStyle| and specifying the color, offset, and blur radius of the shadow.
Draw a horizontal line over the text:
You can combine text decoration using the |TextDecoration.combine| function or the addition operator:
You can combine different styles in one |Text| using the |AnnotatedString| class. The helper function |buildAnnotatedString| allows you to easily append text fragments with different styles.

The recommended approach to displaying text is using string resources instead of hardcoding the values in code.\nThis allows for easier and less error-prone reuse of the same texts as well as preparing your app for internationalization.
You can limit the number of lines displayed for long texts:
Additionally, you can also indicate that the text is overflowing:
Jetpack Compose also provides other fonts: |Default|, |SansSerif|, |Serif|, and |Cursive|. You can also use your own custom font after importing it into the project.
To create a button, you can use the |Button| composable function.\nIt has two required parameters: the content to display and the callback to invoke when the user clicks the button.
To perform some action when the user clicks the button, you can pass a function to the |onClick| callback.
The |remember| and |mutableIntStateOf| will be explained in later lessons.
Jetpack Compose provides 5 predefined types of buttons: filled (default), tonal, outlined, elevated and text.\nYou can one which will fit your app style and its expected beahavoiur.
Another variant of button is the icon button. It ususually contains a single icon (but it can also be something different).\nIt comes in 3 variants: default, filled and outlined.

Icon buttons can also be used as toggles to cycle between checked and unchecked state on each click.\nThey have two required parameters: the current check state (boolean) and funciton to invoke when the state changes.\nIcon toggle buttons come in 3 variations: filled, tonal and outlined.
You can disable button by setting the |enabled|parameter to false.
You can change the colors of a button by creating new |ButtonColors| and passing it to the composable:
You can change the shape of a button by providing custom one.\nPadding of the content can also be specified by the |contentPadding| parameter.
You can add borders to button using the |border| parameter.\nBorder can have solid color or a gradient.
This preview requires API level 30 (Android 11) to work.

Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Quisque in vulputate mi. Interdum et malesuada fames ac ante ipsum primis in faucibus. Vivamus id velit eget velit blandit vestibulum non sit amet leo. Ut condimentum felis ut ipsum convallis, non cursus lorem pellentesque. Nulla blandit tellus a ipsum aliquam commodo id vitae dolor. Donec cursus consectetur mi ut ornare. Maecenas iaculis metus varius sodales porttitor. In et consequat elit, quis auctor odio. Donec vel dolor et nulla accumsan hendrerit.
Modifiers allow you to decorate or change behaviour of a composable.\nAll of previously described composables have optional parameter: the modifier.
The order of applied modifier is significant. Each function makes changes to the modifiers returned by the previous function, which results in the sequence affecting the final result.
In the first example the red background is visibly smaller than in the second, because it is applied after the padding, which limits the space for the following modifiers.

You can change the size of composables by applying the |size|, |height| or |width| modifiers.\nYou can also fill the whole (possibly partially) space by using the |fillMaxSize|, |fillMaxWidth| or |fillMaxHeight|.
You can add margins with the |padding| modifier.\nIt can be used to set the same padding on all sides, on horizontal and vertical, or different one on each side.

If the content doesn\'t, you can enable scrolling of the container.\nModifiers |verticalScroll| and |horizontalScroll| enable scrolling content in corresponding directions.\nYou also need to pass the state of the scroll to these modifiers, usually in the form of |rememberScrollState()| function.
Any composable can become clickable with the |clickable| modifier.\nYou need to pass function to invoke on each click, similar to buttons.
It is also possible to invoke different actions on double and long click.\nYou can achieve this by using the |combinedClickable| modifier.

Composables can also be draggable, by using the |draggable| and |offset| modifiers.\nTo make the dragging work in both axis, you can use the |pointerInput| modifier instead of |draggable| and manually modify the offset in both axis.
When the content can change its size, you can use |animateContentSize| modifier to allow for a smooth transition.
You can blur composable with the |blur| modifier.\nIt requires specifying the blur radius and optionally, how to treat the edges of the blur area.
You can clip content to a specified shape with the |clip| modifier.\nYou can achieve more complex shapes by applying multiple |clip| modifiers.
You can add accessibility information to your interface by using |semantics| modifier.\nIt can specify the role of particular element and describe it state for accessibility services to use.
Modifiers can be conditionally applied by using the |Modifier.then| modifier function.
Modifiers are regular Kotlin objects - you can create one and reuse it in multiple places later.
Text fields allow users to enter text. To create one you can use composable |TextField|.\nIt has two required parameters: currently displayed text and function invoked on change of inputted value.
You can add placeholder to display when the inputted value is empty with the |placeholder|. parameter.
You can limit the text field to only one line by setting the |singleLine| parameter to true.\nYou can also change the minimum and maximum number of visible lines with |minLines| and |maxLines|.
Parameters |enabled| and |readOnly| can be used to disable the text field and disallow text modifications respectively.
You can add more visual information to the text field such as icons and labels using |label|, |supportingText|, |leadingIcon| and |trailingIcon| parameters.
You can also add |prefix| and |suffix| to display around the entered text.

Text can be transformed visually with the |visualTransformation| parameter. This can be useful, for example, when entering passwords or postal codes.\nJetpack Compose provides ready visual transformation for passwords: |PasswordVisualTransformation|.

It is possible to create custom visual transformation. The |CustomVisualTransformation| replaces visible letters with numbers 0–9 based on their position.\nNote that the actual text value is unchanged; it still contains exactly what the user entered.

You can modify the text field to display different keyboard types to the user with the |keyboardOptions| parameter.\nTo make sure that the entered text contains only allowed symbols (e.g. numbers), you can filter the entered text in the |onValueChanged| callback.
You can change the IME action that is displayed on the keyboard, by creating instance of |KeyboardOptions| with specified IME action, and passing it to the composable.
You can change the appearance of the text field by passing custom |TextFieldColors| and |TextStyle| to the composable.

To display an image you can use |Image| composable.\nIt has two required parameters: the painter that is responsible for drawing the image, usually |painterResource|, and |contentDescription| used by accessibility services.\n|Image| can display png, jpg and webp images.
|Image| composable can also display vector graphics.\nThe file describing the graphic should be in xml format.
You can modify the alpha value of the displayed image using the |alpha| parameter.
Parameter |colorFilter| allows for modifying the color values of each pixel in the image.\nYou can use it to change saturation, shift hue or manually adjust the values.
You can also tint images using the |colorFilter| parameter.\nThere are multiple color blend modes available, each resulting in different effects.
You can change how an image is scaled inside it bounds using the |contentScale| parameter.\nIf you don\'t specify this parameter, |ContentScale.Fit| will be used as default.
Cards acts as a containers for application\'s UI.\nCards typically present single coherent piece of content like a news story in a news app or a message in a communicator app.
To create a card you can use the |Card| composable. It has one required parameter: the content to display.
Card can be made clickable by providing function to the |onClick| callback parameter.
Jetpack Compose provides other variants of the cards: the |ElevatedCard| and |OutlinedCard|.
You can customize the colors, shape and border of the card by providing custom values to the |colors|, |shape| and |border| parameters.
A toast is a small popup message that provides feedback about an operation.\nIt takes small amount of space and disappears automatically after a timeout.

To show the toast you first need to instantiate a Toast object.
You can do this using |Toast.makeText| method, which takes the following parameters: the |Context| associated with the message, the text to display and the duration of the toast.
In Jetpack compose, the context can be easily accessed using the |LocalContext.current| composable.
After creating the toast object, you can use |show| method on it to display it on screen.
You can add callbacks to the toast to know when it is shown and hidden.\nTo do this you can create an object inheriting from |Toast.Callback| and register it using the |addCallback| method.
You can limit the time the toast is visible by calling the |cancel| method to hide it early.
Which Composable is used to display text in Jetpack Compose?
How can you change the font size of Text in Jetpack Compose?
Applying the FontModifier to the text
The font size cannot be changed
Which parameter would you use to change the color of Text?
You answered correctly %1$d out of %2$d questions.
What class can store the text and its visual style?

Jetpack Compose is recommended toolkit for building UI for Android apps.\nIt simplifies and accelerates UI development, allowing you to create your app with less code, useful tools and intuitive Kotlin APIs.
In Jetpack Compose, UI elements are created as functions, called composables.\nThese functions describe the UI\'s structure and appearance in a declarative manner.
Changes in state of the composables automatically triggers updates to the UI, removing the need for manual refreshes.
"Jetpack Compose offers several key benefits, compared to traditional XML-based approach: "
Features like live preview, hot reload and full Android Studio support makes developing with Jetpack Compose easier and faster.

For the best experience developing with Compose, download and install Android Studio.\nIt includes many smart editor features, such as new project templates and the ability to immediately preview your UI and animations.
To create a new project that has Jetpack Compose setup correctly, proceed as follows:
Click *Start a new Android Studio project*.
In the *Select a Project Template* window, select *Empty Activity* and click *Next*.
In the *Configure your project* window set the *Name*, *Package name* and *Save location* as you normally would.\nIn the *Minimum API level* dropdown menu, select API level 21 or higher.
Configure the Compose compiler using the *Compose Compiler Gradle* plugin and add the following definition to your app\'s |build.gradle| file:
Setting the |compose| flag to |true| inside the build features block enables Compose functionality in Android Studio.
Finally, add the Compose BOM and the Compose libraries you plan to use in the |dependencies| block:
The fastest way to experiment with the Jetpack Compose is by trying the sample apps.\nTo import a sample app project from Android Studio, proceed as follows:
In the Android Studio welcome screen select *Import an Android code sample*.
In the top search bar type \"compose\".
Select one of the Jetpack Compose sample apps from the search results and click *Next*.
Change the *Application name* and *Project location* or keep the default values.
Android Studio downloads the sample app and open the projects.\nYou can then inspect |MainActivity.kt| file to see example usage of Jetpack Compose APIs.
Running your app on virtual devices
The Android Emulator lets you test your app on many different virtual devices. The emulator is bundled with Android Studio.\nTo use the emulator follow these steps:
64-bit Windows 10 or higher, MacOS 12 or higher, Linux, or ChromeOS operating system
Each instance of the Android Emulator uses and AVD to specify the Android version and hardware of the simulated device.\nTo create an AVD you can use the *Device Manager*.
After creating the AVD you can start the Android Emulator and run your project:
In the toolbar, select the AVD you want to run your app on.
Click *Run*. The emulator might take a while to launch for the first time.
Running your app on a local device

Before you can launch you app on your device you need to enable *USB debugging* in the *Developer options*.\nAfter connecting your device to the computer via USB cable you can click *Run* in Android studio to build and start the application on the device.
Which programming language is primarily used in Jetpack Compose?
What is the name of a UI element in Jetpack Compose?
How is a composable defined in Jetpack Compose?
Which IDE is recommended for Jetpack Compose?
Does Android Studio allow for testing applications on virtual devices?
Yes, using the Phone Virtualization System

Jetpack Compose is built around composable functions.\nThese functions let you define your app\'s UI programmatically by describing how it should look and providing data, rather than focusing on the process of the UI\'s construction.\nTo create a composable function, just add the |@Composable| annotation to the function name.
To display a simple text on the screen, you can use the |Text| composable inside the |setContent| block.\nThe block acts as an entry point for all UI created in Jetpack Compose.
Android Studio should import the required function automatically.\nIf that is not the case you can try to add the import line manually.
Composable functions can only be called from other composables or an entry point (like the |setContent| block).

You can preview your composables within Android Studio by adding the |@Preview| annotation.\nIn order to preview a composable function it must take no explicit parameters.\nA common practice is to create a second function that calls the previous one with the appropriate arguments.

After creating the preview you should rebuild the project.\nThe app itself doesn\'t change, since the preview function isn\'t called anywhere, but Android Studio adds a preview window.\nYou can expand this window by clicking on the split (design/code) view button.
Visible preview window in split screen mode
To use the composable in your app you have to include it in the UI hierarchy by calling it in the entry point.
Some composable accept other composable functions as parameter.\nThis can be useful for creating more advanced layouts without making the code overly complex.
Where can you invoke composable functions?
What annotation can you use to display created composable inside Android Studio?
How can you preview composable that requires some parameters?
In all the places you can invoke regular functions
Only in the file with the MainActivity class
From other composable functions or entry points
By creating wrapper preview function that supplies the parameters
Preview can only be used on parameterless functions
Is it possible to display custom content inside a button?
Yes, you can display any composable inside button
Yes, but only composables annotated with @Interactable are allowed
No, you can put only text inside buttons
What composable you can use to create button with only text visible?
How can you set the number of visible lines in a text field?
With the minLines and maxLines parameters
Only through manipulating the displayed string value
Is it possible to modify the appearance of the inputted text?
Which parameter can be used to display the numeric keypad?
How can you create a Painter object, which is a required parameter of the Image composable?
Painter objects are created automatically for each image
What actions are required to draw a vector graphics using the Image composable?
Specifying the type of the image with the format parameter
The same as when drawing a raster image
On which composables can you apply modifier?
On those that accept Modifier as one of the parameters
Does order of applied modifiers affect the result?
Yes, if the modifier is not annotated as @Stable
is it required to create new modifier for each composable?
No, if the composables are in the same file
Yes, reusing modifiers can create unintended side effects
How can you make card clickable?
By creating a button inside it
By passing callback to the onClick parameter
Is it possble to change shape of the card?
No, cards have constant default shape
Yes, by providing custom Shape object for the shape parameter
